io.s4.processor
Class AbstractPE

java.lang.Object
  io.s4.processor.AbstractPE
All Implemented Interfaces:
ProcessingElement, java.lang.Cloneable
Direct Known Subclasses:
AbstractWindowingPE, JoinPE, PrintEventPE, ReroutePE, SimpleCountingPE
public abstract class AbstractPE
extends java.lang.Object
implements ProcessingElement

This is the base class for processor classes. While it is possible to create a processor class by implementing the ProcessingElement interface, we suggest you instead extend this class.

AbstractProcessor provides output frequency strategies that allow you to configure the rate at which your processor produces output (see setOutputFrequencyByEventCount(int) and setOutputFrequencyByTimeBoundary(int).

public void execute(java.lang.String streamName,

getKeyValue

public java.util.List<java.lang.Object> getKeyValue()
This method returns the key value associated with this PE.

The key value is a list because the key may be a compound (composite) key, in which case the key will have one value for each simple key.

Returns:
the key value as a List of Objects (each element contains the value of a simple key).

setOutputFrequencyByEventCount

public void setOutputFrequencyByEventCount(int outputFrequency)
This method sets the output strategy to "by event count" and specifies how many events trigger a call to the output method.

You would not normally call this method directly, but instead via the S4 configuration file.

After this method is called, AbstractProcessor will call your output method (implemented in your subclass) every outputFrequency events.

If you call neither setOutputFrequencyByEventCount nor setOutputFrequencyByTimeBoundary, the default strategy is "by event count" with an output frequency of 1. (That is, output is called after after each return from processEvent).

Parameters:
outputFrequency - the number of events passed to processEvent before output is called.

setOutputFrequencyByTimeBoundary

public void setOutputFrequencyByTimeBoundary(int outputFrequency)
This method sets the output strategy to "output on time boundary" and specifies the time boundary on which the output should be called.

You would not normally call this method directly, but instead via the S4 configuration file.

outputFrequency specifies the time boundary in seconds. Whenever the current time is a multiple of outputFrequency, AbstractProcessor will call your output method. For example, if you specify an outputFrequency of 3600, AbstractProcessor will call output on every hour boundary (e.g., 11:00:00, 12:00:00, 13:00:00, etc.).

When this output strategy is used, your output method may occasionally (or frequently) run concurrently with your processEvent method. Therefore, you should take steps to protect any data structures that both methods use.

If you call neither setOutputFrequencyByEventCount nor setOutputFrequencyByTimeBoundary, the default strategy is "by event count" with an output frequency of 1. (That is, output is called after after each return from processEvent).

Parameters:
outputFrequency - the time boundary in seconds

setOutputFrequencyOffset

public void setOutputFrequencyOffset(int outputFrequencyOffset)
Set the offset from the time boundary at which AbstractProcessor should call output.

This value is honored only if the "output on time boundary" output strategy is used.

As an example, if you specify an outputFrequency of 3600 and an outputFrequencyOffset of 7, AbstractProcessor will call output on every hour boundary plus 7 seconds (e.g., 11:00:07, 12:00:07, 13:00:07, etc.).

output

public abstract void output()
You implement this abstract method in your subclass. This is the part of your processor that outputs data (e.g., by writing the data to the cache). The output method may further process the data (e.g., aggregate it) before outputting it.
